hawaiian_text: I ia wā, noke aku ana ‘o Nāmakaokapāo‘o i ka  huhuki ā pau kekahi māla ‘uala ā luna o kekahi  māla ‘uala, pēlā nō ka huhuki ‘ana ā pau nā māla  ‘elua ā kū ke āhua o ka lau o ka ‘uala, he kanahā  āhua ka nui o nā māla ‘elua. A laila, ho‘i a‘ela ‘o  Nāmakaokapāo‘o a hō‘ā i ke ahi a ‘ōhinu akula ‘ehā  ‘au o ka ‘uala i luna o kapuahi e ‘ā ana. Iā ia e  ‘ōhinu ana i luna o ke ahi, ho‘i maila kona makua  kāne kōlea ā hiki, nīnau akula i kona makuahine, iā  Pōka‘ī: “‘A‘ole.” ‘Ī aku ‘o Puali‘i: “‘Ae, ‘o ke po‘o  ona a me nā maka ka mea e ‘īna‘i ai ku‘u ‘uala i  kēia lā, no laila, eia kona lā e make ai ia‘u.”
qwen3-235b-a22b-exp-no_think-fireworks_t: At that time, Nāmakaokapāoʻo took to hauling away completely one sweet potato patch atop another sweet potato patch, and in this way he ruined both sweet potato patches until the sweet potato leaves rose up in shape, fourtieth in quantity from the two patches. Then, Nāmakaokapāoʻo returned and lit a fire and roasted several stalks of sweet potato on the fire that was burning. While he was roasting them over the fire, his stepfather came in quickly, arriving, and asked his mother, Pōkaʻī: "No." Pualiʻi said: "Yes, his head and eyes are what I will eat with my sweet potato today, and therefore this is the day I shall kill him."
qwen3-235b-a22b-exp-no_think-fireworks_c:
**Paragraph 6:**
• The passage is deeply symbolic and likely allegorical, consistent with Hawaiian oral tradition's practice of encoding moral, political, and cultural lessons in narrative form.  
• The first section describes Nā-maka-o-ka-pāoʻo’s action of destroying two sweet potato patches—**māla ‘uala**—by tearing them up entirely and stacking one on top of the other until the leaves formed heaps (kanahā āhua). The imagery of tearing up the crops may represent rebellion against subsistence norms or agricultural law, possibly a metaphor for rejecting or threatening the foundations of traditional food customs (like the 'Ai Kapu restrictions).  
• The number **“kanahā āhua” (forty heaps)** may not be literal but symbolic. In Hawaiian cosmology, large round numbers often symbolize abundance and mana (spiritual power), and **forty** could represent a threshold of maturity or transformation, suggesting this act marks a defining shift in the protagonist’s behavior or life status.  
• Nāmakaokapāoʻo then roasts **‘ehā ‘au o ka ‘uala** (four vines of the sweet potato) on a fire **(kapuahi e ‘ā ana)**. Fire rituals were central to traditional Hawaiian religious practice, and the act of roasting food can be priestly, or in this case, subtly subversive if done outside sanctioned contexts or under the instruction of inappropriate authority (such as a child performing adult rites).  
• While cooking, **Pua-(a)liʻi**, his stepfather, returns and asks Pōkaʻī if the child Nā-maka-o-ka-pāoʻo prepared food with him (“'Aʻole"), and she replies “no.” – This exchange shows adherence to Hawaiʻi's **hospitality customs** of inquiring about the food and sharing it with others, particularly with elders or household members.  
• Pualiʻi then replies, “Yes, his head and eyes shall be the food to go with my sweet potato today. Therefore, today is the day I will kill him.” – This is a **threat of human sacrifice or metaphorical condemnation**, but it is laden with **double meanings** relevant to Hawaiian cosmology and agricultural symbolism.  

– The **“poʻo” (head)** and **“maka” (eyes)** referenced here symbolize authority, perception, and spiritual power. The stepfather’s desire to eat Nāmakaokapāoʻo’s head and eyes symbolically suggests a desire to consume or destroy the child’s power, identity, and insight — a metaphor for silencing change or dismissing youthful disruption to the old ways.  
– Pualiʻi eating Nāmakaokapāoʻo's “head” and “eyes” alludes to ritual sacrifice. In this context, Nāmakaokapāoʻo may symbolically represent the **ulua**, the fish traditionally sacrificed in place of a human on temple altars during 'Ai Kapu ceremonies, as noted in earlier examples (Pukui & Elbert 1986:369).  
– However, here the equation is **inverted**: it is **human flesh** (symbolically) being used in **place of sacred food**, and the act is one of **violence**, not ritual reverence. It suggests a breakdown of sacred practice or the old order, and foreshadows conflict.  
• The name **Nā-maka-o-ka-pāoʻo** means “The Eyes of the Pāoʻo fish.” Since **pāoʻo** also can be connected to **poʻo** (head) through sound (a common practice in Hawaiian poetics), the passage creates a clever double entendre — the child's name becomes part of the threat. Eating “the eyes” of the pāoʻo is effectively eating “the eyes of Nāmakaokapāoʻo,” further suggesting ritual cannibalism or symbolic consumption of spiritual vision.

reference_translation: At that time, Nāmakaokapāo‘o was busy tearing  apart the sweet potato patches, yanking them out.  He tore apart both sweet potato patches until  there rose a mound of sweet potato leaves, forty  mounds in all from the two patches. Then  Nāmakaokapāo‘o went back and lit a fire to broil  four sweet potato vines on a fire pit. As he was  broiling the vines, wilting them, his stepfather  came back and reached him and asked   Nāmakaokapāo‘o’s mother, Pōka‘ī, and she said,  “No.” Puali‘i said, “Yes, his head and eyes as food  to go with the sweet potatoes that I’ll eat today.  So, today I will kill him.”
reference_commentary: **Paragraph 6:**• The numbers referred to in this paragraph are  interesting and likely a riddle to solve, with esoteric  meaning: 2, 4, 40\. Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o is a child, but  behaves like a mature adult, albeit destructive and  spiteful, but calculating. This has allegorical meaning  and likely relates to wastefulness and the need to  dismantle ‘Ai Kapu practices.  • Pua-li‘i was so enraged by Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o’s  destruction of the sweet potato patches that he  threatened to eat his head (po‘o) and eyes (nā maka)  with sweet potato in place of ulua fish. The head of  the ulua or of a person likely represents the sweet  potato tuber and the eyes likely represent the sweet  potato vine cutting (maka) that is used to replant and  perpetuate the crop, symbolically, the people of the  land. This also explains the meaning of ʻmaka’ in the  name, Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o, with ʻpāo‘o’ being used  as a poetic reference to ʻpo‘o’ (head).  – Ulua was used as a substitute for human sacrifice  on the heiau in the ‘Ai Kapu culture (footnote: Pukui & Elbert (1986:369) *ulua*: “This fish was substituted for human sacrifices when the latter were not available , probably because of word magic and the meaning of *ulua 2* \[to grow/increase; to be possessed by a god\]. Since an *ulua* replaces a man, *ulua* also means “man, sweetheart,” especially in love songs.”). In this case,  Pua-li‘i threatens to eat the human head and eyes  of Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o in place of the ulua: the  opposite of normal ‘Ai Kapu custom. This appears  to allude to Pua-li‘i’s holding on to the ‘Ai Kapu  customs, going back in time allegorically, rather  than forward in time, where humans are no longer  sacrificed in the Western culture. Nā-maka-o-ka pāo‘o, on the other hand, represents going forward in time, a time of progressive thinking and   abandonment of the ‘Ai Kapu;
